question_text: A cancer patient is dependent on morphine for pain management. His physician decides to switch him to buprenorphine. Due to which property he chooses this new drug?
explanation: Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at the mu receptor with a lower intrinsic activity compared to morphine and hence does not produce withdrawal symptoms in patients with morphine dependence. Buprenorphine is a synthetic thebaine congener and also acts as an antagonist at kappa receptor. It is more potent than morphine at mu receptor but with lower intrinsic activity and ceiling effect. Due to lower intrinsic activity, it has no withdrawal symptoms and can be used in the treatment of morphine dependence.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: An elderly man with bone metastasis is receiving intravenous opioids for pain management. Which of the following drugs can be safely administered to him without a risk of developing respiratory depression?
explanation: Buprenorphine can be safely administered to this patient because of its ceiling effect on respiratory depression. Ceiling effect is defined as no further increase in the effect of the drug with a further increment in dose, once the ceiling level is reached. Opioid agonist-antagonist compounds produce respiratory depression (and analgesia) with a ceiling effect which means increasing the dose further does not produce any further respiratory depression and may actually result in increased ventilation (due to the predominance of antagonist actions). Other drugs that show the ceiling effect are: Butorphano Nalbuphine Pentazocine. Respiratory depression with morphine, fentanyl & alfentanyl does not have a ceiling effect because they are pure opioid agonists. As the dose increases, respiratory depression also increases progressing to respiratory arrest.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text:
Which of the following statements is false?
Naltrexone is an antagonist at µ receptor
options: Meperidine is a pure agonist at µ receptor
Nalbuphine is an agonist at k receptor
Butorphanol is an antagonist at k receptor
explanation: Butorphanol is an agonist at  receptor. It may be a partial agonist or antagonist at µ receptor. Pentazocine, butorphanol, buprenorphine, meptazinol, nalorphine, nalbuphine, and dezocine are mixed agonist-antagonist opioids. All opioid agonist-antagonists are µ antagonists and k agonists, except buprenorphine, pentazocine, and dezocine. Buprenorphine, pentazocine, and dezocine are partial agonists at the  receptor. Option A: Naltrexone is a pure antagonist at µ, k, and  receptors. Option B: Meperidine is a pure agonist of both  and  receptors. Opioid Antagonists
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is a pure opioid antagonist?
explanation: Both naloxone and naltrexone are pure opioid antagonists. Nalorphine is an agonist-antagonist. It has antagonistic activity at the mu receptor and additional agonistic activity at the kappa receptor. Note: Nalmefene is sometimes classified as a pure antagonist but it has additional kappa receptor partial agonist activity.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about opioid antagonists?
options: Naloxone is a short acting drug
Nalmefene can be used for treatment of opioid overdose
Nalmefene is shorter acting than naloxone
explanation: Nalmefene is longer-acting (not shorter-acting) than naloxone.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is false about naltrexone?
options: Is used in the treatment of alcohol dependence
explanation: Naltrexone is more potent than naloxone. Naltrexone is a pure opioid antagonist which is orally active. Alcohol craving is reduced by naltrexone. It is also approved for the prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient is on chronic opioid therapy for pain management. He would not develop tolerance against which of the following actions of opioids?
explanation: Tolerance is developed to all the above actions of opioids except for miosis. Exceptions to opioid tolerance (3C's): Constricted pupil (miosis) Constipation Convulsions
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: An elderly man, who is on chronic morphine therapy for pain relief, visits your clinic with complaints of not passing stools for the last 4 days. Which of the following drugs is best suited to treat his condition?
explanation: The given clinical picture points towards opioid-induced constipation. Methylnaltrexone, an opioid antagonist with predominant peripheral action is best suited for treating opioid-induced constipation. Methylnaltrexone is a peripheral µ receptor antagonist. It was introduced in the treatment of opioid-induced constipation refractory to other measures. It is a quaternary ammonium compound and hence cannot cross the blood-brain barrier. It can reverse the effects mediated by peripheral opioid receptors and spares CNS effects like analgesia. The peripherally acting opioid antagonists include: Methylnaltrexone Naloxego Naldemedine Alvimopan
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is not an antagonist at µ receptor?
explanation: Naltrindole is a new non-peptide drug which has a selective antagonistic activity on the  receptor. This drug is still in the trial phase and is not yet in use. Option B: Naloxone is considered a pure opioid receptor antagonist but at high doses, it is found to have partial agonistic activity on the - and -opioid receptors. Option C: Nalbuphine is an agonist-antagonist opioid which acts as an antagonist at the  receptor and an agonist at the  receptor. Option D: Naltrexone is a -, - and -opioid receptor antagonist.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 27-year-old man presented to the casualty with slurred speech and shallow breathing. On examination, you find he has bradycardia, hypotension, and pin-point pupils. Which drug will you choose to treat him?
explanation: The given clinical features are suggestive of opioid overdose. Naloxone is the drug of choice for opioid overdose. Opioid overdose symptoms: Triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils (miosis) Hypotension, bradycardia Shallow breathing Hypothermia Naloxone is also used for reversing neonatal asphyxia due to opioid usage in labor. Naloxone is a pure opioid antagonist which reverses all effects except sedation. Note: Naloxone is contraindicated in infants born to mothers with opiate addiction as it may precipitate acute neonatal withdrawal with seizures.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A college student who is addicted to intravenous heroin abruptly stopped abusing the drug during exams. Which of the following would you not expect as a part of withdrawal?
explanation: Diarrhea (not constipation) is seen in opioid withdrawal. Opioid withdrawal symptoms (mnemonic- O MY WITHDRAWALS): Mydriasis Yawning Weakness Insomnia, irritability Tremors, tachycardia Hypertension, hyperactive Diarrhea Rhinorrhoea Apnoeic attacks Weight loss Anxiety Lacrimation Sweating
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: An elderly woman who was dependent on morphine for her palliative care recently got switched to another opioid medication. A few days later she started developing withdrawal symptoms. Which of the following opioids would have been prescribed to her?
explanation: Pentazocine can precipitate withdrawal symptoms in opioid-dependent patients. It acts as a weak antagonist or partial agonist at mu-opioid receptors which may precipitate withdrawal symptoms. Options A, C, and D: Pethidine, morphine, and methadone are pure agonists at mu-receptors and do not precipitate withdrawal symptoms.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 33-year-old man with a history of heroin addiction is referred to a rehabilitation center. Which of the following would you use as a substitute drug for maintenance therapy?
explanation: Methadone is used as a substitute drug for the maintenance therapy of opioid (heroin) dependence. This is because of its good oral bioavailability and long half-life. Methadone is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days. Due to its long half-life and accumulation in tissues, discontinuing the drug still results in low concentrations of the drug in plasma resulting in protracted withdrawal symptoms. Maintainance therapy for opioid dependence: Long-acting opioid agonist - a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms Partial agonist - buprenorphine can also be used Clonidine, lofexidine - alpha-2 agonists act as sympatholytic and reduce the withdrawa symptoms LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol) - opioid agonist which reduces craving Naltrexone - is an opioid antagonist used in maintenance therapy to prevent relapses
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A physician prescribes naltrexone to a patient undergoing treatment for opioid addiction. What is the function of this drug in opioid addiction?
explanation: Naltrexone is used for the prevention of relapse in opioid addiction. It is given only after initial opioid detoxification. The patient should be opioid-free for 7-10 days and have a negative naloxone challenge (no withdrawal after naloxone administration). Naltrexone is a pure opioid antagonist which is more potent than naloxone. It is orally active and has a long duration of action which makes it suitable for opioid blockade therapy in post-addicts.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about the use of naltrexone in the treatment of opioid addiction?
options: Discontinuation of naltrexone does not cause withdrawal symptoms
It satisfies craving in opioid addicts
It blocks the effects of opioids if they are used
It is administered only when the patient has completed detoxification from opioids
explanation: Naltrexone does not satisfy the craving of opioid addicts. It is an opioid antagonist with a high affinity for  opioid receptors. Naltrexone does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but it suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics. Opioid agonists such as methadone and buprenorphine suppress craving and withdrawal symptoms and are therefore used in the first stage of detoxification in opioid addiction. Option A: Discontinuation of naltrexone ingestion has no negative physical consequences, as opposed to discontinuation of agonist maintenance therapies, which results in the emergence of opioid withdrawal symptoms. This is a major reason for noncompliance and treatment failure. Option C: It blocks the effects of opioids and prevents the user from experiencing subjective symptoms of opioid intoxication such as euphoria on subsequent use. As the user does not experience these symptoms, he does not develop a craving for the substance. Thus, naltrexone prevents relapse. Option D: It is only administered when the patient has completed a medically supervised detoxification from opioids because it can cause immediate withdrawal symptoms.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text:
You are treating a 31-year-old man with heroin dependence. Which of the following drugs would you not prescribe to him?
Disulfiram
explanation: Disulfiram cannot be used to treat heroin dependence. It is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor used in the maintenance therapy of alcohol abstinence. Maintainance therapy for opioid dependence: Long-acting opioid agonist - a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms Partial agonist - buprenorphine can also be used Clonidine, lofexidine - alpha-2 agonists act as sympatholytic and reduce the withdrawal symptoms LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol) - opioid agonist which reduces craving Naltrexone - is an opioid antagonist used in maintenance therapy to prevent relapses Alcohols
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Effect of acute ethanol consumption is inhibitory on which of the following ligand-gated ion channels?
explanation: The effect of acute ethanol consumption is inhibitory on NMDA receptor-operated channels. Effects of acute ethanol on ion channels: Enhancement GABA-A receptor-operated channels Glycine receptor-operated channels Nicotinic ACh receptor-operated channels 5HT3 receptor-operated channels G protein-coupled inwardly rectifying K+ channels Large conductance, Ca2+/ voltage-activated K+ channels Inhibition NMDA receptor-operated channels Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: The black-outs associated with high levels of ethanol can be attributed to its action on which of the following receptors?
explanation: Blackouts are periods of memory loss that occur with high ethanol consumption and may result from the ability of ethanol to inhibit the action of glutamate on NMDA receptors. NMDA receptor is implicated in many aspects of cognitive function including learning and memory.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Ethanol ingestion results in enhanced diuresis. What is the most probable mechanism causing this?
options: Inhibition of ADH action in collecting tubules
Stimulation of ADH action in collecting tubules
Stimulation of ADH release from pituitary gland
Inhibition of ADH release from pituitary gland
explanation: Ethanol inhibits the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)/ vasopressin from the posterior pituitary gland. This results in enhanced diuresis observed with ethanol ingestion. Inhibition of ADH action in collecting tubules is not the mechanism by which alcohol induces diuresis. Stimulation of ADH release or action will have an antidiuretic action.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: What effect does acute consumption of ethanol have on cytochrome enzymes?
explanation: Acute consumption of ethanol inhibits the function of several cytochrome enzymes that are involved in the metabolism of drugs. CYP2E1 is one of the isoenzymes that is specifically inhibited. Chronic consumption of alcohol causes induction of cytochrome enzymes, particularly CYP2E1, increasing the rate of metabolism of drugs dependent on CYP2E1 for metabolism.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor that you would prescribe for the pharmacological management of a patient addicted to alcohol?
explanation: Disulfiram is an irreversible inhibitor of both cytosolic and mitochondrial forms of aldehyde dehydrogenase. Ethanol consumption during disulfiram therapy can lead to increased concentrations of acetaldehyde. Increased acetaldehyde levels can cause flushing, pulsating headache, throbbing pain in the head and neck, and other aversive reactions. Disulfiram is indicated in alcohol deaddiction maintenance therapy. Option 1: Fomepizole is an inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase. Option 3: Acamprosate is an NMDA receptor antagonist with modest GABA-A receptor agonistic activity. Option 4: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist that suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics. Option 5: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine that can be used to treat acute alcohol withdrawal and anxiety.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 51-year-old diabetic patient presents to your OPD with severe restlessness, palpitations, flushing, and sweating. His medication history includes OHAs and an antibiotic that was started 3 days back. On enquiring, he admits that he consumed two shots of whiskey after taking his medications. Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause similar effects?
explanation: The given clinical presentation is suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction. Metformin is not associated with a disulfiram-like reaction following alcohol ingestion. Disulfiram-like reaction with alcohol ingestion is seen with the following drugs: Metronidazole 1st generation sulfonylureas like chlorpropamide Cephalosporins like cefoperazone, cefamandole Griseofulvin Procarbazine
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 40-year-old man with alcohol dependence is referred to a rehabilitation center for deaddiction. Which of the following drugs would you not prescribe for maintenance of deaddiction?
explanation: Morphine, an opioid receptor agonist, is not indicated for alcohol deaddiction maintenance. Opioid receptor antagonist is indicated for this condition. Drugs approved for the maintenance therapy and to prevent relapse: Naltrexone: It is an orally active opioid receptor antagonist. Acamprosate: An NMDA receptor antagonist with modest GABA-A receptor agonistic activity. Disulfiram: A deterrent drug that works by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following anti-epileptics is effective in maintaining abstinence in a patient undergoing treatment for alcohol deaddiction?
explanation: Topiramate has shown efficacy in maintaining abstinence and reducing craving in chronic alcoholism. Though effective, topiramate is not yet approved for use in alcohol deaddiction maintenance. It is used off-label for this indication. Ondansetron and baclofen are other drugs that are found to be effective but not yet approved for this use.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A young man presented to the ER with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed a bottle of illicit liquor. His ABG shows a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following statements would be incorrect regarding his management?
options: Intravenous ethanol is an alternative to fomepizole
Folinic acid is also used in treatment
explanation: The given clinical picture and labs are suggestive of accidental methanol toxicity. Hemodialysis is used in severe cases of methanol toxicity. A serum methanol concentration greater than 50 mg/dl is serious enough to consider hemodialysis. It can be used to remove both methanol and its toxic metabolite formic acid from the blood. Option A: Fomepizole, an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, is administered intravenously in methanol toxicity. It acts by inhibiting the formation of formic acid. Option B: Intravenous ethanol is an alternative to fomepizole. It has a higher affinity to alcohol dehydrogenase than methanol. Thus, saturation of ADH enzymes results in less formation of toxic formic acid. Option D: Folate-dependent systems are responsible for the oxidation of formic acid to CO2. Both folinic and folic acid are often administered during methanol toxicity but the exact benefit is yet to be determined. Note: Ethanol is given intravenously in the management of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: How is the administration of ethanol going to help in the management of methanol poisoning?
options: Ethanol slows down metabolism of methanol
Ethanol reacts with methanol to form an inactive metabolite
Ethanol reverses the actions of methanol
explanation: Administration of ethanol slows down the metabolism of methanol. Ethanol has a higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase than methanol. Formic acid is the metabolite of methanol which is highly toxic. Therefore, slowing down the metabolism of methanol reduces its toxic effects.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text:
A middle-aged man undergoing treatment for alcohol deaddiction was started on disulfiram. Which of the following statements is true regarding this drug?
When used with alcohol it causes respiratory difficulties
options: It can be initiated even in minimally motivated persons
Its action persists up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug
explanation: Alcohol consumption during disulfiram therapy can lead to increased concentrations of acetaldehyde. This can cause aversive reactions resulting in flushing, pulsating headache, throbbing pain in the head and neck, nausea, vomiting, rashes, respiratory difficulties, chest pain, and autonomic manifestations. Disulfiram is an irreversible inhibitor of both cytosolic and mitochondrial forms of aldehyde dehydrogenase. It is used in behavioral modification for alcohol de-addiction. Option B: The principle of action is aversive conditioning (not anti-craving). Option C: Disulfiram can be given only to highly motivated individuals. It should not be administered until the person has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours. Option D: The disulfiram-alcohol reaction may persist as long as 14 days after the last dose of disulfiram. Drugs for Alzheimer's Disease and Other Neurodegenerative Disorders
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 70-year-old male patient is brought to the OPD by his son, with complaints of increasing forgetfulness. Neuroimaging shows marked cortical atrophy of temporal and parietal lobes. What is the most striking neurochemical disturbance in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease (AD). The most striking neurochemical disturbance in AD is the deficiency of acetylcholine in the subcortical area (especially in the nucleus basalis of Meynert). Neurotransmitters like glutamate and 5-HT and other areas of the brain like the hippocampus are also involved in the pathogenesis of this disease. The drugs used in Alzheimer's disease are: Central acetylcholine esterase inhibitors targeting acetylcholine deficiency NMDA antagonists targeting glutamate excitotoxicity
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is not a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor indicated in a patient with Alzheimer's disease?
explanation: Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist used to treat moderate to severe dementia in Alzheimer's. Donepezil, rivastigmine, and galantamine are reversible cholinesterase inhibitors indicated in Alzheimer's disease. Irreversible antagonists are not indicated in Alzheimer's disease.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A neurology resident changed the current oral medication of a patient with Alzheimer's disease to a transdermal patch of a cholinesterase inhibitor. What must be the new drug that was prescribed?
explanation: Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is available as a transdermal patch for use in Alzheimer's disease. It can be applied for over 24 hours. Transdermal delivery reduces the fluctuation and avoids direct gastric irritation effects associated with oral formulations. Option A: Tacrine is an anticholinesterase that is obsolete because of its association with hepatotoxicity. Options B and D: Donepezil and galantamine transdermal formulations are under development and yet to be available in the market.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following NMDA receptor antagonist would you prescribe to a patient with severe Alzheimer's disease?
explanation: Memantine is a noncompetitive N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist indicated in Alzheimer's disease. It slows the deterioration of patients with moderate and severe Alzheimer's disease. It is claimed to reduce the excitotoxicity of glutamate. Option B - Ketamine is an NMDA receptor antagonist indicated as an anesthetic agent. Option C - Piracetam is a nootropic agent (a drug that enhances cognitive function) that is used off-label to enhance memory. Option D - Amantadine is an antiviral agent with NMDA receptor antagonistic action which is also indicated in Parkinson's disease due to its action on dopamine release and reuptake.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the management of Alzheimer's disease?
options: Monoclonal antibodies can be used in the treatment
Memantine is approved only in moderate to severe disease
Cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine have no effect on behavioral and psychiatric symptoms
explanation: Cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine reduce some of the behavioral and psychiatric symptoms in Alzheimer's disease. SSRIs like citalopram or benzodiazepines for agitation and atypical antipsychotics for psychiatric symptoms may be considered in severe cases. But atypical antipsychotics in dementia-related psychosis have shown higher mortality. Option A - Amyloid beta-directed monoclonal antibodies approved for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease are - lecanemab, donanemab, aducanumab Option B - Cholinesterase inhibitors are commonly used and are considered as first-line in early or mild to moderate stages of Alzheimer's disease. Option C - Memantine is approved only in moderate-severe Alzheimer's disease. There is not enough data to support its use in mild to moderate stages. Note- Aducanumab has been discontinued in the treatment of Alzheimer's
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 35-year-old lady came to the OPD with complaints of occasional shock-like sensations down her spine and muscle spasms. T2 weighted MRI shows typical Dawson fingers and oligoclonal bands were detected in the CSF study. Which of the following is approved for the treatment of her condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of multiple sclerosis. Interferon beta is approved for use in this condition. It reduces the frequency of attacks in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis. The probable mechanisms of action of interferon-beta are: Immune modulation and a decrease in T cell proliferation. Limiting the entry of T cells into CNS. Reducing pro-inflammatory and increasing regulatory cytokines.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: You plan to start disease-modifying therapy in a 40-year-old patient with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis. Which of the following drugs would you not include in the treatment regimen?
explanation: The disease-modifying therapy of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS) does not include methylprednisolone. It is used in acute attacks and exacerbations for MS symptom control. The long-term value or disease-modifying potential of glucocorticoid therapy is unknown. FDA approved disease-modifying therapy of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis are: Interferon-beta 1a Interferon-beta 1b Glatiramer Dimethyl fumarate Teriflunomide Alemtuzumab Natalizumab Fingolimod Mitoxantrone Cladribine
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: John Cunningham (JC) virus antibody titer is being measured in a patient with multiple sclerosis. During treatment with which of the following drugs are the titres mandatory?
explanation: John Cunningham (JC) virus antibody titre measurement is mandatory during treatment with monoclonal antibodies like natalizumab. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a life-threatening disease caused by the JC virus in patients with multiple sclerosis. It is more common when the patient is immunocompromised during their treatment with natalizumab. The current recommendation is to start natalizumab only in a patient who tests negative for JC antibodies. Seroconversion can occur anytime during treatment. Regular monitoring for JC antibody every 6 months is recommended in JC antibody-negative patients on natalizumab.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 30-year-old lady presents with complaints of sudden, involuntary, and uncontrollable dance-like movements. Her mother had also developed similar symptoms at the age of 40. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the treatment of the involuntary movements associated with her condition?
explanation: This patient is most likely suffering from chorea associated with Huntington's disease, for which tetrabenazine is indicated. It is a reversible inhibitor of vesicular monoamine transporter-2 (VMAT-2). Other drugs used in Huntington's disease are: Reserpine, an irreversible inhibitor of VMAT-2 and a longer-acting agent as compared to tetrabenazine. Deutetrabenazine refers to deuterium attached to carbon in place of hydrogen, in tetrabenazine (deuterated tetrabenazine). It is a newer form of tetrabenazine approved for the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington's disease. It slows down its metabolism, hence it is longer acting than tetrabenazine. It is associated with better control of chorea. Option A - Benzhexol is a central anticholinergic indicated in parkinsonism. Option C - Tetrahydrozoline is a topical alpha-adrenergic agonist indicated for the relief of conjunctival congestion. Option D - Benztropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist that can be used for the management of acute dystonia.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of Riluzole?
explanation: Riluzole does not act by causing inhibition of GABA reuptake. Riluzole is the only drug known to improve survival in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease. The mechanism of action involves the reduction of glutamate-induced excitotoxicity by: Inhibition of glutamate release Antagonism of NMDA and kainate-type glutamate receptor Direct action on the voltage-dependent sodium channels.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text:
Which of the following new drugs has been approved for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis?
Edaravone
explanation: Edaravone was approved by the FDA for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). It has free radical scavenging properties that may reduce oxidative stress. The exact mechanism of action is unknown. It is to be administered as an IV infusion with an initial treatment cycle of daily dosing for 14 days, followed by a 14-day drug-free period. Subsequent treatment cycles consist of dosing on 10 of 14 days, followed by a 14 day drug-free period. The major adverse effect of edaravone is hypersensitivity because the infusion contains sodium bisulfite. Other adverse effects include bruising, gait disorder, and headache. Tafinlar (dabrafenib) and Mekinist (trametinib), are both indicated as monotherapy in BRAF V600E/K (BRAF V600E mutation-positive) melanoma. They are approved for combined administration, for the treatment of anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC) that cannot be removed by surgery or that has spread to other parts of the body (metastatic). Piracetam is a nootropic agent (a drug that enhances cognitive function) that is used off-label to enhance memory. It is also used to treat myoclonus. General Principles of Antimicrobial Therapy
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A young man who collapsed at a concert was suspected to have bacterial meningitis. The other attendees of the concert were administered ciprofloxacin by the medical staff on duty. What is this kind of antimicrobial therapy called?
explanation: The antimicrobial treatment initiated in a patient who is not yet infected is called prophylactic therapy. The goal is to prevent infection in some patients and to prevent dangerous manifestations of infections in other patients. Option A: Preemptive therapy is therapy in an asymptomatic individual with evidence of infection (high-risk). Option C: Empirical therapy is broad-spectrum therapy in a patient with symptoms of infection but no microbiological confirmation of the causative agent. Option D: Suppressive therapy is given to patients when the infection is controlled but not completely eradicated by the initial round of antimicrobial treatment. This is usually indicated for immunosuppressed patients.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: The total microbial population was found to be susceptible to antimicrobials on testing but a subset of the same population was resistant which was undetected. What is this phenomenon called?
explanation: Heteroresistance occurs when a subset of the total microbial population is resistant, despite the total microbial population being susceptible on testing. The resistant subpopulation is usually well below the assay-detection limits. Heteroresistant Staphylococci and M. tuberculosis have led to therapeutic failures and mortality. C. albicans and C. neoformans with heteroresistance to fluconazole have resulted in increased treatment failures. Note: For viruses, the resistant viral species occurring due to the above phenomenon is termed as 'quasi-species'. Quasi-species resistant to antiretroviral agents have resulted in the failure of antiretroviral therapy.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following drugs shows concentration-dependent killing?
explanation: Aminoglycosides exhibit concentration-dependent killing and are preferably dosed once daily for maximum effect. Peak concentration above MIC (minimum inhibitory concentration) matters for certain classes of drugs for their antimicrobial action. It is referred to as concentration-dependent killing. The period during which the concentration remains above MIC is not relevant for such drugs. Aminoglycosides and quinolones have this property. Time-dependent killing: The antimicrobial action is dependent on the period for which the concentration of drug remains above the MIC. Penicillins, 5-fluorocytosine and vancomycin have this property.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient having pneumococcal pneumonia could not be treated using penicillin G as the microbe was found to be resistant to it. How is this resistance mainly acquired?
explanation: Transformation is the molecular basis of penicillin G resistance in pneumococci and meningococci.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: What is the extrachromosomal DNA present in bacteria that transmits drug resistance called?
explanation: Drug resistance transmitting extrachromosomal DNA present in bacteria is a plasmid. They are usually involved in the horizontal transfer of drug resistance gene in bacteria. Chromosomal DNA can also be involved in the transfer of resistance.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: How is multidrug resistance transferred among bacteria?
explanation: Multidrug resistance is transferred through conjugation. Multiple genes, each encoding for resistance to a drug can be present in a single bacterial cell. Typically such genes are present on resistance (R) plasmids. The main mode of transfer of resistant gene-containing plasmids is through conjugation.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: An example of a bacteriostatic drug is
explanation: Linezolid is an example of a bacteriostatic drug. Primarily bacteriostatic drugs Primarily bactericidal drugs SulfonamidesErythromycinT etracyclinesClindamycinChlo ramphenicolLinezolidEtham butol Penicillins,CephalosporinsA minoglycosidesVancomycinP olypeptidesCiprofloxacinRifa mpinMetronidazoleIsoniazid CotrimoxazolePyrazinamide
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: You want to prescribe a bactericidal drug to a patient having an infection. Which of the following drugs will you not choose?
explanation: Tigecycline is not a bactericidal drug. Tigecycline belongs to a new class of glycylcyclines which is a congener of teteracycline . It is a protein synthesis inhibitor and generally considered as a bacteriostatic. Isoniazid, daptomycin and ciprofloxacin are all bactericidal agents.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient developed a surgical site infection with Klebsiella, which is found to be sensitive to a cell wall synthesis inhibitor. Which of the following antibiotics is this likely to be?
explanation: Cefepime is an antibiotic that acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin. Cephalosporins act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. Aminoglycosides, doxycycline, and erythromycin are protein synthesis inhibitors.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient has presented to your OPD complaining of vomiting and rice water stools. You decide to treat him with a protein synthesis inhibitor. Which antibiotic do you choose?
explanation: Doxycycline is a tetracycline that acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. It is the drug of choice for cholera. Options A & D: Cefotetan and oxacillin are beta-lactam antibiotics that act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. Option C: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that acts by inhibiting DNA gyrase.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following antibacterial agents does not act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis?
explanation: Nitrofurantoin is an antibacterial drug that does not act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. The antibacterial activity of nitrofurantoin appears to correlate with the rapid intracellular conversion of nitrofurantoin to highly reactive intermediates by bacterial reductases. These intermediates react nonspecifically with many ribosomal proteins and disrupt the synthesis of proteins, RNA, DNA, and metabolic processes. Carbapenems, monobactams, and cephalosporins are beta-lactam antibiotics that act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text:
You are studying the susceptibility of Streptococci to bacitracin in the lab. What is the site of action of this drug?
Cell wall
explanation: Bacitracin acts on the cell wall by inhibiting the synthesis of the cell wall. It interferes with the dephosphorylation of bactoprenol (lipid carrier) which carries peptidoglycan subunits outside the cell membrane to the growing cell wall. It can also alter the integrity of the cell membrane. Bacitracin is mainly active against gram-positive cocci and bacilli. Antimalarial Drugs
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following antimalarial drugs is a slow acting schizonticide?
explanation: Pyrimethamine is a slow-acting schizonticide. Female Anopheles mosquito inoculates Plasmodium species in the form of sporozoites into the human host during blood meal. Sporozoites migrate to the liver and mature into hepatic schizonts. Hepatic schizonts are released into the blood in the form of merozoites. Merozoites in the erythrocyte transform into ring form and erythrocytic schizonts. Some merozoites in the blood transform into gametocytes. Antimalarial drugs are classified based on their onset of action of schizonticidal function as below: Fast onset of action Artemisinin derivatives like artemether , arteether and artesunate are fastest acting Chloroquine Intermediate onset of action Mefloquine Quinine Proguani Lumefantrine Slow onset of action Pyrimethamine Sulfonamides Tetracyclines Clindamycin
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is gametocidal to all the species causing malaria?
explanation: Primaquine is gametocidal to all species causing malaria. It inhibits transmission of malaria. The drugs with clinically important gametocidal activity (against all species) are: High activity: Artemisinins Primaquine Low to moderate activity: Chloroquine Quinine Atovaquone/proguani No activity: Mefloquine Pyrimethamine Sulfadoxine Tetracycline
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A researcher who was studying plasmodium species decided to visit a malaria-endemic place in Odisha to do his clinical study for 5 weeks. He is planning to leave after 2 days. Which of the following drugs can be taken as prophylaxis before visiting the malaria-endemic place?
explanation: Doxycycline can be taken as prophylaxis by the researcher before going to malaria-endemic places. Chemoprophylaxis against malaria for travelers: If the duration of travel is less than 6 weeks then doxycycline 100mg once a day is to be started 2 days before travel and continued atleast 4 weeks after travel. If the duration of travel is more than 6 weeks then mefloquine 250mg once a week is to be started 2 weeks before travel and continued atleast 4 weeks after travel.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 35-year-old woman presented with fever and chills. Peripheral blood smear revealed findings suggestive of P. vivax malaria. Which among the following is the most appropriate drug for this patient?
explanation: Most approproate drug for the treatment of malaria due to P. vivax is chloroquine. P. vivax treatment recommendations are: Chloroquine-susceptible infections: Chloroquine or artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT). Chloroquine-resistant infections: ACT is the drug of choice but quinine is used during 1st trimester of pregnancy. In the absence of resistance data in the question, chloroquine appears to be the most appropriate answer.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Radical cure is required for malaria caused by which of the following species?
explanation: Radical cure is required for malaria caused by P. vivax and P. ovale. In case of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale, malarial parasites have an exoerythrocytic stage (hypnozoites). In the exoerythrocytic phase malarial parasites are found in the liver that can cause relapse of malaria after clinical cure. Therefore, they require radical cure by drugs acting on the exoerythrocytic stage. Primaquine is effective against the exoerythrocytic stages of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale in the liver. Primaquine is administered for 14 days for radical cure.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Tafenoquine is used in which of the following conditions?
options: Treatment of malaria in children <2 years
explanation: Tafenoquine is used in the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax. Total eradication of plasmodium species which includes clinical curative and hypnozoites phase are called radical cure. Primaquine and tafenoquine (derivative of primaquine) have very high activity against the latent tissue forms (hypnozoites) of the species. It is primarily used for the chemoprophylaxis and radical cure of P. vivax and P. ovale infections.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Chloroquine is not useful in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
explanation: Chloroquine is used in the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus, porphyria cutanea tarda and giardiasis, due to its anti-inflammatory effect; but it is not used in the treatment of Sjogren's Syndrome. Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine concentrate in lysosomes and have an anti-inflammatory effect. It also has antihistaminic and antiarrhythmic properties. Non-antimalarial uses of choloroquine are: Hepatic amoebiasis Giardiasis Rheumatoid arthritis Systemic lupus erythematosus Discoid lupus erythematosus Porphyria cutanea tarda Severe polymorphous light eruption
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 26-year-old woman who is 10 weeks pregnant, comes with history of fever and chills. She is diagnosed with falciparum malaria. Which of the following drugs will you choose for her treatment?
explanation: The woman is in the 1st trimester of pregnancy and falciparum malaria during 1st trimester of pregnancy is treated with quinine plus clindamycin. Worldwide, most species of Falciparum malaria are resistant to chloroquine. In all trimesters, pregnant women diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria caused by chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum infection can be treated with a combination of quinine and clindamycin. Quinine is considered the drug of choice in the first trimester. In the second and third trimesters artemether-lumefantrine can be used, but not in the first trimester. Vivax malaria during pregnancy is treated with chloroquine as chloroquine is safe in pregnancy and children. Clindamycin can be used in children for chloroquine-resistant cases. It is safe to use in children and pregnant women. Option B: Doxycycline is useful in the treatment of malaria but not used in pregnancy. Options C and D: Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) is not recommended during the 1st trimester of pregnancy because of a lack of safety data.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 32-year-old man presents with fever with chills and seizures. On examination, his blood pressure was 70/50 mm of Hg and labored breathing was present. Routine blood investigations revealed Hb of 4.8 g/dl. ABG was done and the pH was 7.21. Findings in peripheral blood smear are shown below. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
explanation: This scenario depicts a case of severe complicated falciparum malaria, and the drug of choice in this condition is artesunate. The image shows ring forms/early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) and this is characteristic of P. falciparum malaria. Severe complicated malaria is caused by P. falciparum and is characterized by hyperparasitemia, hyperpyrexia, acidosis, respiratory distress, bleeding manifestation, cardiovascular collapse, renal failure and cerebral malaria. As per WHO guidelines, all patients with severe malaria should be treated with intravenous or intramuscular artesunate for at least 24 hours. Once the patient recovers and can tolerate oral medications, oral ACT for 3 days is recommended. Artemether is used only if parenteral artesunate is not available.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is not a WHO recommended artemisinin-based combination therapy?
explanation: WHO recommended artemisinin-based combination therapies are: Artemether plus lumefantrine Artesunate plus pyrimethamine-sulfadoxine Artesunate plus mefloquine Artesunate plus amodiaquine Dihydroartemisinin plus piperaquine
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: You are posted in a health centre in Nagaland as part of your rural service and a patient is diagnosed with uncomplicated falciparum malaria. Which of the following artemisinin-based combination therapy is recommended by NVBDCP for this patient?
explanation: The artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) recommended by NVBDCP in the north-eastern states is a combination of artemether and lumefantrine. NVBDCP guidelines for the treatment of uncomplicated falciparum cases: North-eastern states: Artemether-lumefantrine based ACT Rest of the country: Artesunate-sulfadoxine+pyrimethamine In the north-eastern states (Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Manipur, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, and Tripura), the presently recommended ACT for P. falciparum malaria is a fixed-dose combination of artemether-lumefantrine due to the recent reports of late treatment failures with the current combination of AS+SP.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Loading dose is essential for chloroquine because of which of the following properties?
explanation: Loading dose is essential for chloroquine because of its property of high volume of distribution. Chloroquine is distributed extensively in the liver, spleen, kidney, lungs, skin and, to a lesser extent, brain and spinal cord. Because of extensive tissue binding, a loading dose is required for achieving effective plasma concentrations earlier in the therapy.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: While writing a prescription for a patient diagnosed with malaria, the medical officer instructed the patient to take a particular drug along with a high fatty meal. Identify the drug.
explanation: The drug described here is lumefantrine and its absorption increases when it is administered along with fatty food or milk because it is highly lipophilic.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient who was diagnosed with malaria was initiated on treatment about 3 days ago. Now she presents with seizures and confusion. Which of the following drugs is most likely to have caused this condition?
explanation: The case depicts neuropsychiatric adverse effects which are commonly associated with the use of mefloquine. The US FDA has put a "black box warning" for this drug due to permanent and serious neuropsychiatric side effects. The CNS toxicity caused by mefloquine includes: Seizures Acute psychosis Severe vertigo Confusion or decreased sensorium
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: The finding shown in the image below is seen as a side effect of which of the following drugs?
explanation: The finding shown in the image is bulls-eye maculopathy, and chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine use are associated with this side effect. Bull's-eye maculopathy refers to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of a central area of retinal pigment epithelial depigmentation surrounded by relatively normal retinal pigment epithelium, giving a bull's-eye appearance to the macula.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A pregnant patient with severe malaria is undergoing treatment with quinine. Which of the following adverse effects is not associated with this drug?
explanation: Quinine is not associated with hypertension. It is associated with hypotension. Quinine is used in the treatment of drug-resistant and severe P. falciparum malaria. It acts against asexual erythrocytic forms but has no significant effect on hepatic forms of malarial parasites. Option A: Quinine use is associated with cinchonism which manifests as tinnitus, visual and auditory disturbances, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Option B: Quinine has a stimulatory effect on pancreatic beta cells and can cause hypoglycemia. Option D: Blackwater fever is a rare type of hypersensitivity reaction to quinine. It presents with massive hemolysis, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria that may lead to anuria, renal failure, and death.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text:
A patient who was initiated on treatment for malaria two days ago, now presents with complaints of passage of dark-colored urine. Hemolysis due to G6PD deficiency is suspected. With which of the following drugs is this condition more common?
Quinine
explanation: Hemolysis in a G6PD deficient patient is more common with primaquine. G6PD deficient patients are highly sensitive to oxidative stress. They are at increased risk of hemolysis due to the oxidant property of primaquine. Therefore, before initiating primaquine therapy, the G6PD status of the patient has to be determined. Passage of dark color urine is an indication of hemolysis and the drug has to be stopped if it occurs. Quinine, chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can also cause hemolysis in G6PD deficient patients, but the incidence is less compared to primaquine. Sulfonamides , Quinolones and Urinary antiseptics
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Sulfonamides are structural analogs of which of the following compounds?
explanation: Sulfonamides are structural analogs of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) that interfere in the synthesis of folic acid. Sulfonamides competitively inhibit dihydropteroate synthase, the enzyme that is involved in the incorporation of PABA into pteridine (dihyropteroate diphosphate) to form dihydropteroic acid, which is an immediate precursor of folic acid.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is not a topically used sulfonamide?
explanation: Sulfasalazine is a sulfonamide which is not used topically. It is used orally in the management of ulcerative colitis, rheumatoid arthritis, and regional enteritis. Sulfacetamide is used topically as eye drops for ophthalmic infections. Silver sulfadiazine and mafenide are used topically for the prevention of burn infections.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Trimethoprim is an inhibitor of which of the following enzymes?
explanation: Trimethoprim is a selective inhibitor of microbial dihydrofolate reductase. Dihydrofolate reductase is involved in the reduction of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following combinations is indicated for the prophylaxis of malaria?
explanation: Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine combination is used for prophylaxis and treatment of malaria caused by mefloquine-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum. Sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim is used in the treatment of Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. Sulfadiazine-pyrimethamine is used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following options correctly describes the dose ratio of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole in co-trimoxazole?
explanation: Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the dose ratio of 1:5 (trimethoprim : sulfamethoxazole). The antimicrobial activity of this combination is because of its actions on sequential steps in the pathway of synthesis of tetrahydrofolic acid as shown in the image. Each agent alone usually exerts bacteriostatic activity. But when an organism is sensitive to both agents, bactericidal activity may be achieved. Because trimethoprim is more lipid-soluble than sulfamethoxazole, it has a larger volume of distribution than the latter drug. Therefore, when 1 part of trimethoprim is given with 5 parts of sulfamethoxazole (dose ratio is 1:5; trimethoprim:sulfamethoxazole), the peak plasma concentrations are in the ratio of 1:20, which is optimal for the combined effects of these drugs in vitro.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia prophylaxis in a patient who has undergone organ transplantation?
explanation: Cotrimoxazole is considered the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia prophylaxis in immunocompromised patients like patients who have undergone organ transplantation and HIV-positive patients. Other drugs that can be used for prophylaxis are: Aerosolized pentamidine Dapsone Dapsone plus pyrimethamine Atovoquone
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Co-trimoxazole is not prescribed in which of the following conditions?
explanation: Chancroid was earlier treated with cotrimoxazole but it is not used anymore because better alternatives like ceftriaxone, azithromycin, erythromycin, and ciprofloxacin exist. Options B & C: Cotrimoxazole is indicated in both upper and lower urinary tract infections and also in prostatitis. Option D: Patients with severe nocardiosis are initially treated with a combination including cotrimoxazole, amikacin, and ceftriaxone or imipenem.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: An infant had a serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. The mother might have taken which of the following drugs during the third trimester for this to occur?
explanation: Cotrimoxazole is a combination drug consisting of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, of which sulfamethoxazole is a sulfonamide. Sulphonamides displace bilirubin from plasma albumin, leading to elevation of serum bilirubin levels. These drugs can cross the placenta and are secreted in milk and can therefore cause kernicterus in newborn infants if they are given to pregnant women near term or during lactation.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A girl presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain, dark-colored urine, and seizures. You find out that she was recently prescribed co-trimoxazole for a UTI. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given neurovisceral symptoms following the use of sulfonamides point towards a diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria (AIP). AIP is a rare heme biosynthesis disorder due to a partial deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase (PBGD). Diagnosis is made based on elevated urine PBG levels. Alcohol, infections, pregnancy, and certain medications can trigger attacks by inducing heme synthesis. This results in the accumulation of porphyrin precursors, causing symptoms. Side effects of sulfonamides are: Acute intermittent porphyria - sulphonamides precipitate attacks Hypersensitivity reaction - urticaria, erythema nodosum, erythema multiforme of the Stevens-Johnson type, exfoliative dermatitis, and photosensitivity Crystalluria - due to low solubility. It is treated with good hydration and alkalization of urine Hemolysis in G-6-PD deficiency (sulphonamides are oxidizers) Kernicterus in the newborn (displace bilirubin)
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: What is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones in gram-negative bacteria?
explanation: Fluoroquinolones inhibit two essential type II topoisomerases, DNA gyrase (in gram-negative bacteria) and topoisomerase IV (in gram-positive bacteria). DNA gyrase introduces negative supercoils and thereby reduces the torsional strain that occurs when double-stranded DNA is being unwound for replication or translation. Topoisomerases IV is responsible for unlinking daughter chromosomes after replication. Quinolone antibiotics form a complex with the topoisomerase enzyme and the DNA, and thereby block DNA replication and bacterial cell division.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following fluoroquinolones has maximum bioavailability?
explanation: Levofloxacin and ofloxacin have the maximum bioavailability among fluoroquinolones. Hence, intravenous and oral doses are the same for these drugs.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient who is a known case of cystic fibrosis presents to the OPD with complaints of fever and increased cough with expectoration. Sputum culture is positive for Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following fluoroquinolones can be used in this condition?
explanation: Ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin have substantial activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and can be used in this patient. Mild to moderate respiratory exacerbations owing to Pseudomonas aeruginosa in patients with cystic fibrosis respond to oral ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin therapy. Activity against streptococci is significantly greater with newer quinolones like levofloxacin, gemifloxacin, and moxifloxacin. Moxifloxacin has clinically significant activity against anaerobes including B. fragilis. It is reported to have similar efficacy to piperacillin-tazobactam for complicated intra-abdominal infection.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following quinolones is not approved for use in a patient diagnosed with urinary tract infection?
explanation: Moxifloxacin does not accumulate significantly in urine and is not approved for the treatment of urinary tract infections (UTIs). UTIs are the only indication for the use of nalidixic acid. Ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin can be used in UTIs caused by susceptible organisms.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient presents with a wound on his leg with purulent discharge. Pus culture was positive for MRSA. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe?
explanation: Delafloxacin is a newer fluoroquinolone approved for use in acute bacterial skin and skin structural infections (ABSSSI) caused by susceptible bacteria including MRSA. Compared to other fluoroquinolones which are zwitterionic in nature, delafloxacin is anionic. This enables the molecule to achieve increased intracellular penetration and concentration, especially under acidic conditions (skin wounds). This results in increased antimicrobial activity and a decreased adverse event profile at clinically potent doses.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following fluoroquinolones can be used in a patient with rifampicin-resistant leprosy?
explanation: Ofloxacin can be used in this patient as it is the fluoroquinolone that has high activity against M. leprae and is indicated in alternative multidrug therapy regimens for leprosy. It also has high activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient presents to the OPD with sudden onset abdominal cramps, fever, and diarrhea. He is a foreigner who is on a tour in India and is a known asthmatic on theophylline. You decide to start antibiotics. However, you would avoid ciprofloxacin in this patient because .
options: Ciprofloxacin decreases the effect of theophylline
explanation: Ciprofloxacin should not be given to this patient because it is a cytochrome P450 inhibitor and inhibits the metabolism of theophylline and can potentially lead to theophylline toxicity. Pefloxacin is another drug that inhibits the metabolism of theophylline and results in its toxicity.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 52-year-old man diagnosed with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis requires second-line agents for his therapy. However, he is found to have a creatinine clearance of 50 ml/min. Which of the following fluoroquinolones can be started in this patient without dosage adjustment?
explanation: Moxifloxacin is metabolized predominantly by the liver and hence can be used safely in patients with decreased renal function without dose adjustment. Fluoroquinolones, especially moxifloxacin, may be used as part of multiple-drug regimens for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. Most of the available fluoroquinolones are cleared predominantly by kidneys and dosage needs to be adjusted in patients with renal failure. But fluoroquinolones such as moxifloxacin and pefloxacin undergo hepatic elimination and so should be used carefully in patients with liver disease.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 65-year-old man presents with symptoms suggestive of Achilles tendon rupture. He had undergone renal transplantation and is now being treated with an antimicrobial agent. Which of the following antimicrobials might he be on?
explanation: Among the following options, the most likely drug to have caused this condition is ciprofloxacin, since Achilles tendon rupture and tendinitis are side effects of quinolones. Elderly patients (>60 years), patients on corticosteroids and solid organ transplant recipients are at higher risk.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A 60-year-old woman undergoing treatment with moxifloxacin was brought to the casualty with delirium and seizures. According to her son, she had been taking diclofenac tablets over the counter to relieve her ankle pain, which recently started. Which of the following best describes the reason for her current ER admission?
options: Enhanced GABA binding to its receptor
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a fluoroquinolones drug interaction, where NSAIDs augmented the displacement of GABA from its receptors, leading to CNS excitation symptoms. Fluoroquinolones act as selective antagonists of GABAA receptors and thereby have the potential to cause CNS excitation. NSAIDs such as diclofenac cause the displacement of GABA from its receptors, further enhancing the neuropsychiatric adverse effects caused by fluoroquinolones.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: The ECG of a patient undergoing treatment with a quinolone is given below and you notice that QTc = 477 ms. Which of the following drugs has the highest risk of causing this condition?
explanation: The given scenario describes QT interval prolongation (Normal QTc = 440 ms). Among the given options, moxifloxacin has the highest risk for causing this condition. Gemifloxacin, ofloxacin, and ciprofloxacin have a relatively lower risk than moxifloxacin. Ciprofloxacin has the least risk for QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes. Sparfloxacin has the highest overall risk of QT prolongation and has been withdrawn from many countries due to its propensity to cause torsades de pointes or polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Withdrawn Fluoroquinolones Associated Adverse Events Sparfloxacin and Gatifloxacin Phototoxicity, QTc prolongati on Trovafloxacin Hepatotoxicity Gatifloxacin Hypoglycemia Grepafloxacin Cardiotoxicity Temafloxacin Immune hemolytic anemia Clinafloxacin Phototoxicity
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is a urinary antiseptic?
explanation: Methenamine is a urinary antiseptic and is indicated in urinary tract infections. At pH<5.5, methenamine releases formaldehyde that inhibits bacteria. Option A: Galantamine is a central anticholinesterase approved for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. Option C: Mecamylamine is a ganglionic blocker that can be used as an antihypertensive agent. Option D: Pyrimethamine is an antimalarial agent.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following drugs would you prescribe to a patient in order to relieve pain due to urinary tract infection?
explanation: Phenazopyridine can be prescribed to this patient since it is a urinary anesthetic. It is used as a local anesthetic in urinary tract disorders to relieve the pain of lower urinary tract irritation, as in cystitis, urethritis, or prostatitis. It does not have any antibacterial action but affords symptomatic relief of burning sensation, dysuria and urgency due to cystitis.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient presents to the casualty with fever with chills and chest pain. He also gives history of passing brown-colored urine. He was prescribed an antimicrobial drug for urinary tract infection three days ago and his symptoms began after he had started this medication. Which of the following antimicrobial agents had most likely been prescribed?
explanation: The patient had most likely been prescribed nitrofurantoin as the scenario depicts side effects of this drug. Nitrofurantoin is a urinary antiseptic used against lower UTI caused by E.coli and enterococci. Its use results in brown urine. It is also associated with acute pneumonitis with fever, chills, cough, dyspnea, chest pain, pulmonary infiltration, and eosinophilia within hours to days of initiation of therapy. The symptoms resolve quickly after discontinuation of the drug. The antibacterial activity of nitrofurantoin is due to its intracellular conversion to highly reactive intermediates by bacterial reductases. These intermediates react nonspecifically with ribosomal proteins and disrupt the synthesis of proteins, RNA, DNA, and other metabolic processes.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text:
Which of the following fluoroquinolone is not given in liver disease?
Ofloxacin
Levofloxacin
Pefloxacin
explanation: Pefloxacin is mainly metabolized in the liver and hence avoided in patients with liver disease. Quinolones with primarily hepatic metabolism include moxifloxacin, pefloxacin, and trovafloxacin (withdrawn from the market due to hepatotoxicity). Quinolones primarily excreted by the kidneys include ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, norfloxacin, lomefloxacin, and ofloxacin. Antimicrobials Acting on 30s Subunit
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis is undergoing treatment with streptomycin. Which of the following is the primary intracellular site of action of this drug?
explanation: Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and the primary intracellular site of action of aminoglycosides is the 30S ribosomal subunit. Mechanism of action of aminoglycosides: Aminoglycosides are transported actively across the cell membrane into the cytoplasm (oxygen-dependent process) Binding of aminoglycosides to 30S ribosomes cause misreading of mRNA template and result in incorporation of incorrect amino acids in the growing polypeptide chain The resulting aberrant proteins may be inserted into the cell membrane leading to altered permeability of the cell membrane of bacteria causing bacterial death (bactericidal)
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following statements about aminoglycosides is false?
options: They are excreted unchanged in urine
explanation: Aminoglycosides are rapid bactericidal agents. Aminoglycosides like streptomycin and tobramycin cause hearing loss in a newborn child when taken during pregnancy. They are polar compounds and are excreted usually unchanged in the urine. They are distributed mainly in the extracellular compartment. Primarily bacteriostatic drugs are: Sulfonamides Erythromycin Tetracyclines Clindamycin Chloramphenicol Linezolid Ethambutol Primarily bactericidal drugs are: Penicillins Cephalosporins Aminoglycosides Vancomycin Polypeptides Ciprofloxacin Rifampin Metronidazole Isoniazid Cotrimoxazole Pyrazinamide
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A young man working in a rabbit farm presents with fever, lymphadenopathy and an ulcer on the hand and is diagnosed with tularemia. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
explanation: Streptomycin (if not available, gentamicin) is considered the drug of choice for the treatment of tularemia. Tularemia is caused by Francisella tularensis, an aerobic gram-negative bacteria.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A child presented with recurrent episodes of cough with expectoration. Investigations revealed a positive sweat chloride test. Inhalational formulation of which of the following aminoglycosides is approved for use in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. Inhalational formulation of tobramycin is approved for use in cystic fibrosis patients with Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections. Option A: Injectable formulation of amikacin is used in cystic fibrosis. Options B & D: Inhalational formulations of gentamicin and streptomycin are available but they are usually not used. Note: The question is about approved inhalational formulation.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: The organisms detected in culture and sensitivity reports of various specimens obtained from the patients from a medical ward are given below. In which of the following infections would amikacin not be indicated?
explanation: Amikacin has less activity against enterococci and hence is not indicated in infections caused by this organism. In enterococcal infections, gentamicin along with penicillin (or ampicillin) is given. Amikacin is used against serious nosocomial gram-negative bacillary infections which are resistant to gentamicin and tobramycin. It has good activity against most strains of the following organisms: Pseudomonas aeruginosa Serratia Proteus Klebsiella Enterobacter Escherichia coli
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Oral neomycin will not be effective for treating which of the following patients?
options: A patient requiring pre-operative antisepsis for bowel surgery
A elderly man with hepatic encephalopathy
A child with enteropathogenic E. coli associated diarrhea
A woman with a cut wound on the finger
explanation: Topical neomycin is used widely for a variety of infections of the skin and mucous membranes and to prevent infection of minor cuts and wounds. Oral neomycin can be used for the eradication of bacteria confined to GIT in the following conditions: Pre-operative antisepsis for bowel surgery Hepatic encephalopathy: To reduce deleterious ammonia producing bacteria Enteropathogenic E. coli associated diarrhea Orally administered neomycin is poorly absorbed from the GI tract and is eliminated unchanged in the feces. Neomycin is highly nephrotoxic in human beings and hence should not be administered systemically.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient with hospital-acquired pneumonia is being treated with an aminoglycoside antibiotic by a single daily dose administration method. This method is preferred over the multiple daily dosage method because of which of the following properties of aminoglycosides?
explanation: Single daily dose aminoglycoside administration is more preferable to multiple daily dose administration because of the long post-antibiotic effect. For certain classes of drugs such as aminoglycosides and quinolones, its antimicrobial action is dependent on the peak concentration above MIC (Minimum Inhibitory Concentration). It is referred to as concentration-dependent killing. High-dose, extended-interval dosing schemes take advantage of the concentration-dependent activity of aminoglycosides to achieve maximal initial bacterial killing. And then because of the postantibiotic effect of aminoglycosides, good therapeutic response can be attained even when concentrations fall below MIC for a substantial fraction of the dosing interval. Therefore, a single daily dose would be equal to or more effective than multiple 8 hourly doses. This dosing strategy may also reduce the ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity of these drugs. Time-dependent killing is an effect seen when the antimicrobial action is dependent on the duration, the drug concentration remains above the MIC. Beta-lactams, macrolides, and vancomycin have this property.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient who was diagnosed with urinary tract infection receives a single intramuscular dose of gentamicin. Within how many minutes of administration is the peak concentration of this drug achieved?
explanation: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and the peak concentration of aminoglycosides following intramuscular administration is achieved after 30-90 minutes. Aminoglycosides need therapeutic dose monitoring because of their low therapeutic index especially in patients in whom renal function is compromised. Both trough and peak levels are calculated for aminoglycosides.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: The urine culture and sensitivity report of a patient with urinary tract infection is positive for aminoglycoside-resistant Enterococcus faecalis. What is the most common mode of this resistance?
options: Inhibition of transport across bacterial membranes
Drug efflux mechanism through the membrane
explanation: Clinically, the most common cause of aminoglycoside resistance is drug inactivation by enzymes. The inactivating enzymes are commonly acquired through conjugation and transfer of plasmids containing resistance genes. Causes of aminoglycoside resistance are: Drug inactivation by enzymes Increased drug efflux Decreased permeability to the dru Modifications of the 30S ribosomal subunit that interferes with binding of the aminoglycosides
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: In which of the following patients will you prescribe aminoglycosides at a lower dose?
options: A urosepsis patient with associated AKI
A cystic fibrosis patient with acute pulmonary exacerbation
A diabetic patient with infected burn wounds
explanation: The dose of aminoglycosides is to be reduced in patients with renal failure (AKI) because clearance of the drug is reduced. Aminoglycosides undergo minimum metabolism and are primarily excreted almost entirely by glomerular filtration. Therefore, renal failure decreases the clearance of the drug. Because the incidence of nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity is likely related to the overall exposure to aminoglycosides, it is critical to reduce the maintenance dose and dosing interval of these drugs in patients with impaired renal function. Option B: Renal clearances are increased and the half-life is reduced in cystic fibrosis patients necessitating higher doses. Option C: Burn patients have a more rapid drug clearance probably due to increased drug loss through burnt tissue and require higher doses in them. Option D: Aminoglycoside dose adjustment is not required in liver disease
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient who was on aminoglycoside therapy presents with nausea and vomiting. Investigations revealed rising serum creatinine levels, and granular casts were seen on urine microscopy. Which of the following aminoglycosides is least likely to cause this condition?
explanation: The scenario depicts a case of aminoglycoside-induced nephrotoxicity and the least nephrotoxic among aminoglycosides is streptomycin because it does not concentrate in the renal cortex. Among aminoglycosides, neomycin has the highest and streptomycin has the least nephrotoxicity. Adverse effects of aminoglycosides are: Nephorotoxicity Ototoxicity Acute neuromuscular blockade and apnea Hypersensitivity reactions (rare)
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Vestibular toxicity is predominantly seen with which of the following aminoglycosides?
explanation: Vestibular toxicity is predominantly seen with streptomycin and gentamicin. Ototoxicity seen with aminoglycosides: Cochlear toxicity (high-pitched tinnitus) - amikacin, kanamycin, neomycin Vestibular toxicity (moderately intense headache and vertigo) - streptomycin > gentamicin Both vestibular toxicity and cochlear toxicity - tobramycin
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: A patient who was recently started on i.v. gentamicin for enterococcal endocarditis presented to the OPD with complaints of headache and dizziness. By which of the following mechanisms does the drug cause this adverse effect?
options: Inhibition of hair cell Na+/K+ ATPase
explanation: The scenario depicts a case of gentamicin-induced ototoxicity which is caused due to direct hair cell toxicity. Degeneration of vestibular hair cells and neurons leads to vertigo and associated headache. Streptomycin and gentamicin produce predominantly vestibular effects. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin primarily affect auditory function. Tobramycin affects both equally.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: An elderly patient who was taken up for an emergency laparotomy showed prolonged respiratory depression which did not resolve with neostigmine. On inquiry, the attendant confirmed that the patient was on aminoglycoside therapy. Which of the following is least likely to cause this effect?
explanation: The given scenario depicts the neuromuscular blockade effect of aminoglycosides, and tobramycin has the least potency for blockade in this group. Decreasing order of potency for the neuromuscular blockade is: Neomycin > Kanamycin > Amikacin > Gentamicin > Tobramycin It is a recognized clinical side effect of aminoglycoside antibiotics, and this effect becomes significant (prolonged respiratory depression) when the drug is used in conjunction with neuromuscular blocking agents or calcium channel blockers. They are avoided in patients with myasthenia gravis. Aminoglycosides cause neuromuscular blockade by interfering with calcium channels and thereby inhibiting acetylcholine's pre-junctional release and post-junctional sensitivity. The neuromuscular blockade produced by these antibiotics is not reversed by neostigmine but is reversed by IV calcium gluconate.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
explanation: Doxycycline is the drug of choice for scrub typhus. Azithromycin, chloramphenicol, or rifampin can be administered as alternatives in patients allergic to doxycycline and in pregnancy.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: By which of the following mechanisms do tetracyclines inhibit protein synthesis?
options: Inhibition of initiation of translation and misreading of mRNA
Binding to 30S subunit and inhibiting the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to A site
Binding to 30S subunit and inhibiting peptide bond formation
Inhibits binding of aminoacyl-t-RNA to 50s subunit of ribosome
explanation: Tetracyclines inhibit protein synthesis by binding to 30s subunit and inhibiting the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the A (acceptor) site of the mRNA – ribosome complex.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Which of the following organisms is resistant to tetracyclines?
explanation: All strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are resistant to the action of tetracyclines. Tetracyclines are active against MRSA and MSSA. Doxycycline and minocycline can be used in cutaneous MRSA infections. Rickettsia and chlamydia are highly susceptible to tetracyclines. Tetracyclines are considered first line agents for chlamydial infections like non-specific urethritis/ endocervicitis and rickettsial infections like typhus, rocky mountain spotted fever, Q fever. They are also second-line drugs in patients with syphilis who are allergic to penicillin. Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic drugs which are more active against gram-positive than gram-negative. They are effective against spirochetes, Haemophilus ducreyi, Vibrio cholera, Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: In patients with which of the following conditions is doxycycline not used?
explanation: Doxycycline is not used in typhoid infection. Enterobacteriaceae and gram-negative anaerobes are resistant to tetracyclines, hence doxycycline is not used in intraabdominal infections. Third-generation cephalosporins and quinolones are used in treating typhoid fever. Doxycycline treatment for 21 days is the first-line therapy for lymphogranuloma venereum. It is also indicated as one of the first-line treatments for borreliosis. Doxycycline is the alternative to penicillin for the treatment of leptospirosis.
subject: Pharmacology

question_text: Tetracycline is used for the prophylaxis of which of the following conditions?
explanation: Tetracycline is used for the prophylaxis of cholera. It is recommended for close contacts of a case of cholera. It is supposed to be effective in preventing spread. Doxycycline in combination with rifampicin is used for prophylaxis of brucellosis. It is also used in the prophylaxis of leptospirosis. Note: The question is about the drug tetracycline and not about the class of tetracyclines as a whole.
